Cluster Analysis via Gaussian Mixture Models

Matthias Kloft

2025-11-23

Source: vignettes/articles/04-Gaussian_Mixture.qmd

Overview

This document demonstrates the Gaussian Mixture Model interpretation feature of the psychinterpreter package using the Big Five personality data from the psych package. The Big Five Inventory (BFI) is a widely-used personality assessment that measures five major dimensions of personality: Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, and Neuroticism.

It also covers the labeling of variables using large language models (LLMs) to create short labels for better interpretability.

Setup and Data Preparation

Code
packages <- c(
  "psychinterpreter",
  "ellmer",
  "ollamar",
  "psych",
  "lavaan",
  "mirt",
  "mclust",
  "dplyr",
  "here",
  "kableExtra",
  "pander",
  "patchwork"
)
# Load required packages using pacman
if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman")
Loading required package: pacman
Code
pacman::p_load(char = packages)

# Load the BFI dataset and dictionary
data("bfi")
data("bfi.dictionary")

Preparing the BFI Data

Exclude demographic variables for factor analysis

Code
bfi <- bfi[,1:25]
bfi.dictionary <- bfi.dictionary[1:25, ]

Show the first few rows of the BFI data:

Code
head(bfi,10) |> DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE))

Display the BFI dictionary showing item descriptions:

Code
bfi.dictionary |> select(Item) |> as.data.frame()|> DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE))

Create Short Labels

Create variable information dataframe from BFI dictionary

Code
variable_info <- data.frame(
  variable = rownames(bfi.dictionary),
  description = as.character(bfi.dictionary$Item),
  stringsAsFactors = FALSE
)

head(variable_info) |> DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE))
Code
provider <- "anthropic"
llm <- ellmer::models_anthropic()[1,"id"]
Code
bfi_labels <- label_variables(
  variable_info = variable_info,
  llm_provider = provider,
  llm_model = llm,
  llm_args  = list(params(temperature = 0, seed = 42)),#
  max_words = 3,
  sep = "_",
  case = "title"
)

Replace variable names with short labels and update variable_info for later use

Code
labels <- paste(bfi_labels$labels_formatted$variable, bfi_labels$labels_formatted$label, sep = "-")
colnames(bfi) <- labels
variable_info$variable <- labels

Cluster Analysis (Gaussian Mixture Model)

Find Best Gaussian Mixture Model

Code
gmm_model <- mclustICL(ggplot2::remove_missing(bfi), G = 1:10, prior = priorControl())
Warning: Removed 364 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale
range.
Code
summary(gmm_model)
Best ICL values:
             VEV,2         VVV,2        EEE,4
ICL      -197755.8 -197781.82699 -197932.1079
ICL diff       0.0     -26.05329    -176.3342
Code
plot(gmm_model)

Fit the Best Model

Code
best_model <- pickBIC(gmm_model)
# extract model name from best_model$names
model_name <- names(best_model)[1] |> stringr::str_extract("[A-Z]{3}")
n_clusters <- names(best_model)[1] |> stringr::str_extract("[1-9]") |> as.integer()
# Run mclust with automatic model and cluster selection
gm_result <- mclust::Mclust(
  ggplot2::remove_missing(bfi),
  G = n_clusters,
  modelNames = model_name,
  warn = TRUE,
  prior = priorControl()
)
Warning: Removed 364 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale
range.
Code
summary(gm_result)
----------------------------------------------------
Gaussian finite mixture model fitted by EM algorithm
----------------------------------------------------

Mclust VEV (ellipsoidal, equal shape) model with 2 components:

Prior: defaultPrior()

 log-likelihood    n  df       BIC       ICL
      -96046.49 2436 677 -197372.3 -197755.7

Clustering table:
   1    2
1196 1240

LLM Interpretation

Code
# Get interpretation
result <- interpret(
  fit_results = gm_result,
  variable_info = variable_info,
  llm_provider = provider,
  llm_model = llm,
  weight_by_uncertainty = TRUE,
  word_limit = 50
)
ℹ Starting gm interpretation...
ℹ Creating temporary chat session...
ℹ Building prompt...
ℹ Querying LLM...
ℹ Parsing LLM response...
ℹ Creating fit summary...
ℹ Building report...
✔ Interpretation complete!

Suggested Cluster Names
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

• Cluster 1 (48.4%): Engaged Conscientious Achievers
• Cluster 2 (51.6%): Emotionally Reserved Pragmatists




Cluster Interpretations
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Cluster_1: "Engaged Conscientious Achievers" (n=1179, 48.4%)
  High empathy and conscientiousness with strong interpersonal engagement. Exceptionally organized planners who pursue
  perfection. Socially confident with excellent communication skills. Experiences moderate emotional reactivity,
  particularly anger and irritability. Intellectually curious and reflective. Low indifference to others. Well-defined,
  emotionally responsive achievers balancing ambition with genuine concern for people.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

Cluster_2: "Emotionally Reserved Pragmatists" (n=1257, 51.6%)
  Greater emotional distance and introversion with stronger neuroticism patterns. More difficulty approaching others and
  talking socially, with less social magnetism. Moderate conscientiousness and planning orientation. Elevated emotional
  reactivity—particularly stronger anger-irritability correlation and sadness. Shows emotional withdrawal linked to
  social difficulty. More reflective about emotional states. Lower social engagement despite adequate capabilities.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════




Diagnostics
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────


  Warnings:
    Poor cluster separation detected (minimum distance: 1.37)


  Notes:
    Overlapping cluster pairs: Cluster_1-Cluster_2



Key Distinguishing Variables
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────


  Cluster_1: "Engaged Conscientious Achievers":
    - E4-Makes_Friends_Easily (4.98 vs 4.43)
    - A3-Comforts_Others_Well (5.1 vs 4.61)
    - E2-Difficulty_Approaching_Others (2.66 vs 3.14)


  Cluster_2: "Emotionally Reserved Pragmatists":
    - E4-Makes_Friends_Easily (3.87 vs 4.43)
    - A3-Comforts_Others_Well (4.13 vs 4.61)
    - E2-Difficulty_Approaching_Others (3.62 vs 3.14)

Visualization

Code
plot(
  result,
  what = c("means", "variances"),
  plot_type = "parallel",
  centering = "global",
  orientation = "vertical",
  variable_order = "variance_reversed"
) +
  ggplot2::theme(legend.position = "top")
`centering` only applies to 'means' plots, ignoring for: "variances"

Generic API

We may also extract the mean vector, covariance matrix, mixing proportions, and membership grades from the model fit and provide it directly to interpret(). This is the appropriate workflow for models that are not directly supported by psychinterpreter.

Code
# Means
gmm_means <- gm_result$parameters$mean

# Covariance Matrix:
gmm_covariances <- gm_result$parameters$variance$sigma

# Mixing proportions
gmm_proportions <- gm_result$parameters$pro

# z matrix as the membership grades for every person
gmm_z <- gm_result$z

Let’s first take a look at the required arguments for the generic interpretation function:

Code
show_interpret_args("gm")
── Llm args (llm_args) ──
  additional_info (character)
  Default: "NULL"
  Additional context for LLM
  echo (character)
  Default: "\"none\""
  Allowed: "none", "output", "all"
  Echo level: 'none', 'output', 'all'
  interpretation_guidelines (character)
  Default: "NULL"
  Custom interpretation guidelines for LLM
  llm_model (character)
  Default: "NULL"
  LLM model name (e.g., 'gpt-4o-mini', 'claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022')
  llm_provider (character (required))
  Default: "NULL"
  LLM provider name (e.g., 'anthropic', 'openai', 'ollama')
  params (list)
  Default: "NULL"
  ellmer params object (created via ellmer::params())
  system_prompt (character)
  Default: "NULL"
  Custom system prompt to override default
  word_limit (integer)
  Default: "150"
  Range: 20-500
  Maximum words for LLM interpretations
── Output args (output_args) ──
  format (character)
  Default: "\"cli\""
  Allowed: "cli", "markdown"
  Output format: 'cli' or 'markdown'
  heading_level (integer)
  Default: "1"
  Range: 1-6
  Markdown heading level (1-6)
  max_line_length (integer)
  Default: "80"
  Range: 40-300
  Maximum line length for text wrapping (40-300)
  silent (integer)
  Default: "0"
  Range: 0-2
  Verbosity level: 0 (report+messages), 1 (messages only), 2 (silent)
  suppress_heading (logical)
  Default: "FALSE"
  Suppress main heading in output
── Interpretation args (interpretation_args) - GM specific ──
  covariance_type (character)
  Default: "NULL"
  Allowed: "EII", "VII", "EEI", "VEI", "EVI", "VVI", "EEE", "VEE", "EVE",
  "VVE", "EEV", "VEV", "EVV", "VVV"
  Covariance structure for mclust models (GM only)
  min_cluster_size (integer)
  Default: "5"
  Range: 1-100
  Minimum meaningful cluster size for diagnostics (GM only)
  n_clusters (integer)
  Default: "NULL"
  Range: 1-100
  Number of clusters (GM only)
  plot_type (character)
  Default: "\"auto\""
  Allowed: "auto", "heatmap", "parallel", "radar", "all"
  Visualization type for cluster profiles (GM only)
  profile_variables (character)
  Default: "NULL"
  Subset of variables to focus on for interpretation (GM only)
  separation_threshold (numeric)
  Default: "0.3"
  Range: 0-1
  Overlap threshold for cluster separation diagnostics (GM only)
  weight_by_uncertainty (logical)
  Default: "FALSE"
  Weight interpretations by cluster assignment certainty (GM only)

Interpretation with generic API

Code
generic_result <- interpret(
  fit_results = list(
    means = gmm_means,
    covariances = gmm_covariances,
    proportions = gmm_proportions,
    z_matrix = gmm_z
  ),
  variable_info = variable_info,
  analysis_type = "gm",
  llm_provider = provider,
  llm_model = llm,
  weight_by_uncertainty = TRUE,
  word_limit = 50
)
ℹ Starting gm interpretation...
ℹ Creating temporary chat session...
ℹ Building prompt...
ℹ Querying LLM...
ℹ Parsing LLM response...
ℹ Creating fit summary...
ℹ Building report...
✔ Interpretation complete!

Gaussian Mixture Model Interpretation: 2 Clusters
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Number of clusters: 2
Number of variables: 25
Number of observations: NA
Minimum cluster separation: 1.370
LLM used: anthropic - claude-haiku-4-5-20251001
Tokens:
  Input: 0
  Output: 0
Elapsed time: 5.03




Suggested Cluster Names
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

• Cluster 1 (48.4%): Warm Conscientious Leaders
• Cluster 2 (51.6%): Reserved Emotionally Intense




Cluster Interpretations
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Cluster_1: "Warm Conscientious Leaders" (n=NA, 48.4%)
  High empathy and conscientiousness define this cluster. Members excel at comforting others, inquire about well-being,
  and make friends easily. They're exacting in work, pursue perfectionism, and plan carefully. Moderate neuroticism and
  talkativeness suggest balanced emotional regulation. Strong within-cluster correlations show empathic and
  conscientiousness traits cluster together, creating socially skilled, organized individuals with stable leadership
  potential.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

Cluster_2: "Reserved Emotionally Intense" (n=NA, 51.6%)
  This cluster exhibits higher emotional reactivity and introversion despite comparable conscientiousness. Members show
  greater indifference to others, talk less, and struggle approaching people, though still maintain empathic
  capabilities. Notably elevated neuroticism correlations (anger-irritability r=0.76) indicate heightened emotional
  volatility. Stronger connections between shyness and negative affect suggest withdrawn individuals experiencing more
  pronounced mood disturbances, reflecting a more emotionally turbulent yet conscientious personality profile.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════




Diagnostics
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────


  Warnings:
    Poor cluster separation detected (minimum distance: 1.37)


  Notes:
    Overlapping cluster pairs: Cluster_1-Cluster_2



Key Distinguishing Variables
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────


  Cluster_1: "Warm Conscientious Leaders":
    - E4-Makes_Friends_Easily (4.98 vs 4.43)
    - A3-Comforts_Others_Well (5.1 vs 4.61)
    - E2-Difficulty_Approaching_Others (2.66 vs 3.14)


  Cluster_2: "Reserved Emotionally Intense":
    - E4-Makes_Friends_Easily (3.87 vs 4.43)
    - A3-Comforts_Others_Well (4.13 vs 4.61)
    - E2-Difficulty_Approaching_Others (3.62 vs 3.14)
